conversations.value: You know, Star-Lord, this place kind of reminds me of my old apartment. Pre-Ant-Man era, of course. What do you think those papers are all about? Alien schematics, or just someone's old tax returns?

Dude, I've seen cleaner parts of a Contraxian bazaar. And trust me, they don't have taxes. But this mess could totally hide some wicked space tech blueprints. Or... it might just be a recipe for some kick-butt Earth tacos.
Tacos would be good about now. So, check this out—I bet I could shrink down and tidy this place up in, like, five seconds flat. Hold my tacos, right?
Five seconds? Ha! That's not a cleanup, that's like a reverse heist. And what's the deal with that mattress? Is it floating? Giants don't even sleep on clouds, and trust me, I've met a Celestial.
Floating mattress... you might be onto something. Quantum levitation, perhaps? Or just a trick of perspective. Either way, we'd need the Wasp’s take on this mystery. She’s the expert on small spaces.
Man, if only we had a black light, Quill CSI style. Bet this room's got some stories. And hey, that map on the wall! Is that for treasure, you think? 'Cause I'm all about finding hidden loot.

Haha, easy, Indiana Quill. Before you start swinging a whip around, let's consider it might be just a map to the nearest laundromat. Because from the look of that pile of clothes, someone could use a spin cycle.

Laundromats, treasure maps... on Earth, treasure is hide-and-seek. In space, it's more like dodge-the-death-rays and don't-get-eaten. I prefer my treasure hunts with a side of danger. Makes the victory dance so much sweeter.

Hey, I’m all for victory dances. But usually after I save the world, not so much with the laundry. Anyway, wouldn't you like to shrink down sometimes, sneak past all the danger, grab the loot, and be back in time for the victory jam?

Shrink down, huh? I gotta admit, that does sound pretty primo. Less dodging, more rocking. Still, I'd miss the looks on their faces when they see Star-Lord outsmarting them. It's all about the drama, Scotty.
Drama's good and all, but sometimes you just gotta be willing to take the backseat—let the small victories build up. Although, a part of me does miss the thrill of those close calls. Not gonna lie.
Yeah, I hear ya. But look at us now, huh? Bigger things to worry about than messy rooms and possibly non-existent treasure maps. Like saving the galaxy. Again.
Couldn’t have said it better myself, Star-Lord. For now, though, let's grab those tacos and save the world one bite at a time.
Now that's a plan with no flaws, Ant-Man. Lead the way to taco glory.
This sign, it’s pointing in lots of directions. Different paths, reminds Hulk of bifrost and gateways to other worlds.

Yeah, kind of the crossroads of travel, big guy. Earth's got lots of these. They're like waypoints; 'cept without the need for celestial navigation. Though, gotta admit, not as flashy as Asgardian magic.
Hulk thinks it’s confusing. Too many words. Hulk likes smashing, not reading signs.
Oh man, you'd have to get in line with the rest of us trying to decipher Earth's road signs. But imagine, dude, if you could just smash your way to your destination. Actually, nevermind, bad idea...
Smash not always answer...
Well, that's some serious character development there, Hulk! Proud of you, man. So, what do you think, which way to the fun? I bet you ten units it's towards the VIP entrance.
“VIP entrance” sounds like special treatment. Hulk likes feeling special, not angry.
That's the spirit! VIP all the way! We should find a sweet ride, maybe trick it out with some space tech – have our own little 'Hulk and Star-Lord: Earth Road Trip'.
Hulk thinks that’s a good plan. Maybe drive through walls if traffic too much.
Haha, buddy, remind me to never let you behind the wheel. Actually, Hulk, you ever tried hover-biking? It's like riding a jet without the pesky need for wings.
Hulk would try. But hover-bike must be Hulk-sized.
Leave it to me, I'll talk to Rocket. If he can build bombs out of scraps, a Hulk-sized hover-bike is like a walk in the park for him.
Then we ride to get churros. Tony talk about churros. He say they good.
Churros? Oh, man! I haven't had one of those in ages. They're the stuff of legends. Sweet, sugary, cinnamon-y legends. It's a deal, Hulk. Churros it is!
Road trip with churros and Star-Lord. Hulk think this will be fun.
Best plan ever. We'll have a blast and, who knows, maybe save the world on the way to dessert. Just another day for the Guardians and the Avengers, right?
Right. Hulk ready. When do we start?
So, what do we got here, Star-Lord? Looks like a guy from the early 2000s rocking some serious gaming action. You ever get into these old-school games?

Totally. Back on Earth, I was all about that arcade life. But this, my friend, might be one of those ancient relics my mom mentioned called a "Wii". It was like cutting-edge tech before I got zapped into space.
Right? It's a classic. I remember playing these with Cassie during my not-so-lawful house arrest days. We’d pretend we're in the game – saving the world, you know?

Man, pretending to save the world is great and all, but we do that on a daily basis now. To be honest, I wouldn't mind kicking back and racing some virtual go-karts instead of running from whatever galaxy-ending calamity is on our tail this week.
A little downtime with Mario Kart sounds perfect. Kinda makes you miss the simple days of Home Consoles. What’s your go-to character?
Always bet on the underdog, buddy. Luigi – the man's a legend. Always in the shadow of his brother but just as heroic. Kinda relate to him on a personal level. What about you?
Got to represent the insect kingdom, right? So I’m usually buzzing around with that little mushroom guy, Toad. Quick and agile, just how I like it.
Heh, gotta admire your consistency, Ant-Man. But look at this guy in the picture though, he's totally absorbed. The focus is intense. That's how you know it's a good game.
100%. That's the face of a dude on a critical mission. I know that expression. It's the same one I have when I'm about an inch tall trying to reroute circuits in a security system.
And that's the same focus I bring when I'm jamming to an '80s hit while dodging blaster fire. Only difference is I've got better dance moves than most gamers.
Is that a challenge? Because I’ll have you know, I can hold my own on the dance floor... or in a living room gaming sesh.
Keep dreaming, Antsy. For now, let's just appreciate this guy's solo mojo. Tomorrow it's back to saving the galaxy, but tonight, we celebrate the unsung heroes – the gamers.
Hear, hear. To the gamers and to us having our slice of downtime. Now, let's find ourselves a console and hit the pixelated racetrack, Star-Lord!
Game on, my tiny friend. But don't get too comfy in first place. The legendary outlaw Star-Lord doesn't like coming in second.
Well, would you look at that. Reminds me of the good old days, plain and simple. You ever notice how something ordinary can take you back, Peter?

Nostalgia isn't really my thing, Cap. But I gotta admit, there’s something kinda... I dunno, comforting about this scene. Makes me think of a track from my Awesome Mix. Maybe something by Looking Glass?
Looking Glass, uh? That's '70s, right? I've been trying to catch up with the music I missed. Never imagined a bathroom might be where I'd get trip down memory lane, though.
You're in for a treat with '70s music, man. And hey, you're staring at a classic Earth bathroom, something I haven't seen in... a while. No high-tech gadgets, just good ol' soap and water.
It's the simple things that make life worth living, I find. And looking at this, it seems everyone has the same basic needs, no matter what planet you’re from.
Couldn't agree more. Except, you know, I wouldn't mind if the towel was fluffier. And the bathmat. In space, everything is... less cozy.
I suppose the comfort of home is universal. By the way, the cleanliness here is commendable. Hygiene is important, wouldn’t you say?
Definitely, Cap. Even in space, we gotta keep things clean. Makes you feel human, or at least half-human in my case. Sure beats a bucket and a sponge!
I’ll take your word for it, Star-Lord. It's these small pieces of Earth you miss the most out there among the stars, isn't it?

You could say that. Little things like this remind me that no matter how far I go, I've still got a home to come back to. Anyway, ready to save the galaxy again, or are you just gonna stand there admiring the bathroom tiles?
The galaxy isn't going to save itself. Let's get moving, Star-Lord. Duty calls.
Right behind you, Cap. And just for the record, that is America's shower curtain.

It appears this is a form of terrestrial locomotion, a "train" from the early to mid-20th century, if my knowledge serves correctly. Wakanda has long since progressed beyond such technology. Tell me, Star-Lord, do trains hold any significance in your Earthly experiences?

Oh man, yeah. Trains are classic Earth stuff. Kids love 'em, especially the old-school ones like this. My mom and I used to lay coins on the tracks when we went to the countryside – wait for a train to flatten them. It's kinda like a retro pastime, you know?
A curious tradition indeed. Would these machines not be considered artifacts from your perspective now, worthy of preservation rather than used for such purposes?

For sure, dude. I don't think I'd go laying coins on museum pieces. But back in the day, no one thought twice about it. Everything old becomes new again at some point, though – nostalgia, or something like that. What's transportation like in Wakanda now?

In Wakanda, we utilize mag-lev technology and advanced propulsion systems that harness the power of vibranium. It eliminates friction and greatly reduces the environmental impact. We strive for harmony with nature.
Vibranium-powered mag-levs, huh? That's hardcore. We don't have anything that fancy, just some cool spaceship tech. Although, flying the Milano is a bit different than catching the A-train.
The Milano, that is your ship, is it not? I must admit, the freedom to explore the stars does sound quite appealing. Though, as king, my place is with my people, ensuring their future.

Yeah, nothing beats cruising through the cosmos with some classic tunes. But hey, I get the whole duty-to-your-people gig. We both have our roles, huh? Saving galaxies, protecting nations. It's what we signed up for.
Indeed, Star-Lord. Our paths, different as they may be, align in purpose – to protect and to serve. Whether it is through strength of arm or heart, we stand in the face of adversity.
Couldn't have said it better myself, your Highness. Now, next time you're on Earth, maybe I can show you around. I think you'd dig some of our old tech – just for kicks, you know?
I would be honored, Star-Lord. It would be enlightening to experience more of Earth's history firsthand. Though, I believe I will leave the coin-flattening to the memories of your youth.
Deal. But I'm bringing you Earth's finest mixtape – get ready for some real old-school vibes!
Music is a vibrant part of any culture; I anticipate it with great interest. Wakanda forever, Star-Lord.
And Guardians forever, my friend. Let's save the world to the sound of some sweet tunes.
Peter, do you ever miss the simplicity of Earth? This image, it reminds me of a quiet yet intricate ballet of machines, all working together in harmony.
Yeah, Wanda, I do sometimes. Trucks lined up like mixtapes in a row, waiting to hit the road. It's not the Milano, but there's a certain charm to it, a rhythm like an old song from back home.
Each one carrying stories, goods, a part of someone's life moving from one place to another. It's rather... grounding to see such ordinary yet essential movements of human life.

You’ve got a poetic way of seeing things. Back on Earth, I probably wouldn't have given trucks a second glance unless they were in an action-packed car chase. But out here, it makes me remember the small stuff matters too.

I suppose sometimes we overlook the everyday magic around us when we're caught up in the bigger picture. We both have seen the vastness of the universe, yet this humbling human scene still catches our eye.

Speakin' of magic, you could probably teleport a whole fleet of these with a wave of your hand, huh? But seriously, it's about the journey, not the destination, or so they say. Kind of fits with us — always running around the galaxy.

Indeed, but despite the chaos in our lives, there's solace in the idea of a path laid out before you, much like these trucks ready to embark on their next journey. It's a controlled chaos, predictable yet necessary.

Controlled chaos, I like that. It's pretty much the Guardian's motto at this point. And hey, if we ever need a change of pace, we can always hijack one of these rigs and take it for a spin across the States — Star-Lord and the Scarlet Witch on a road trip. Now there’s a headline.
Take a look at this, Peter. That's something you don't see every day. In the middle of a busy street – a dancer, lost in the music and movement.
Whoa, Cap! She's just getting down in public? That's the kind of boldness I can get behind. Earth really has changed since the '40s, huh?
It certainly has. Back in my day, a dance number would draw a crowd, not just side glances. There's a sort of fearlessness to it that I admire.
Fearlessness, exactly! It's like me rocking out to my Awesome Mix in the middle of a skirmish. You gotta find joy wherever you can, even if the world's all kinds of serious.
It reminds me of the way we face adversity. Whether it's taking to the streets to dance or standing up against a cosmic tyrant, being true to yourself takes courage.
And hey, check out the guy on the right – he's got that "just another day on the commute" face. I bet he's seen weirder stuff.
That's the world now, a mix of extraordinary and ordinary, all woven into one tapestry. It's fascinating, the diversity of experiences, even in a simple moment like this.
You hit the nail on the head, man. Earth's full of contrasts. Makes me almost miss the chaos of growing up in space. Almost.
There’s a certain beauty in the chaos, Peter. Keeps things interesting. Makes you appreciate the dance all the more.
Got that right, Cap. Now, if only we had some tunes, I'd show you some moves myself!
I'll take your word on that, Star-Lord. Maybe one day, you'll get to teach me one of those dances.
You're on, Cap! Next time we save the galaxy, we're celebrating with a dance-off. Prepare yourself, it's going to be epic.

Look at this image, a simple moment yet so heavy with meaning. It's not unlike my attempts at creating a perfect reality, don't you think? It's the small, mundane moments that we often desire the most.

Huh, never took you for a baseball fan, Wanda. But you're right. Reminds me of simpler times on Terra—Earth, I mean. Just hanging out, no cosmic threats or evil robots. And man, snagging an autograph from a big-league player? That was the dream.
Baseball was never a part of my life in Sokovia, but now I see its charm. It's fascinating how such a simple gesture can mean the world to someone. The joy on the kid's face says it all.

That’s true. It’s like when I got my first Troll doll from Yondu. Felt like the biggest deal in the galaxy. Though, I think he actually pinched it from some unsuspecting kid... still, it's the thought that counts, right?
The intent behind our actions indeed holds power. Yet, so does the action itself. To that child, this moment is a pivotal memory—he will forever remember the kindness.
Yep, you got that right. He's probably gonna go home, put the ball on a shelf, and tell everybody about it. Maybe fly it around, make spaceship noises—uh, not that I ever did that with my stuff...
This picture, it’s a reminder that our legacies can be built from such fleeting moments of joy and kindness. It’s... reassuring.
Whoa, Wanda getting all deep on me. I like it. Makes me think about what kind of legacy I’m leavin’ behind. Hopefully, it’s more “Awesome Mix Vol. 1” and less “galactic wanted poster.”

We strive for significance in our grand actions, yet often it's the smallest moments that echo in eternity. We share the desire to leave a positive imprint upon the world, in whatever form it manifests.

Speaking of small moments, I think I'll take a leaf out of this guy's playbook. Maybe hand out some signed Star-Lord gear to the young Terrans. Spread some goodwill and get that positive legacy thing going.
That sounds like a wonderful idea, Star-Lord. I'm sure it will light up someone's world, just as this athlete has with his gesture.
Alright, it's settled then. And hey, maybe I'll find some way to get that to happen across the multiverse too. Star-Lord autographs for everyone!
May it bring you the kind of joy we're witnessing here, Peter.
Thanks, Wanda. You know, you should consider it too. A Scarlet Witch spell, souvenir edition or something. Could be a hit!
Perhaps, in the right moment and the right reality, I just might. For now, this picture is enough.

This individual engages in physical competition. Such activities require discipline and effort. Tell me, Star-Lord, do you perceive this as a trivial pursuit, or is there some merit in this form of human contest?
Ha, merit? You kidding me? Sports are like the soul of humanity, man. Brings people together, pushes them to be their best. Plus, it's a blast to watch. Ever seen a Grand Slam final? It's epic!
Your enthusiasm for competition is intriguing. It is a form of battle, yet nonlethal. I suppose a universe where such things can thrive is one benefit of balance.

Balance, huh? Look, I'm not about to agree with your methods, but I get what you're saying. Tennis here, it's like a personal battle. A way to prove yourself without, you know, snapping away problems.
Proving oneself... I respect that. In every being, there is a deep-seated need to demonstrate one's worth through trials. Perhaps in another life, I might have appreciated this simpler combat.
Simpler? Maybe. But not easy. And trials? You sure love that word. But hey, imagine this – tennis, but with Infinity Stones as the ball. Now that'd be a match I'd like to see!

An amusing thought, Star-Lord, wielding the Stones in such a frivolous manner. Yet, harnessing their power demands more than mere sport. It requires responsibility and the will to enact necessary change.
Necessary change, right. Well, in the name of fun, I’ll stick to blasting tunes from my Zune and leaving the universe-altering stuff to the professionals. Or at least, those who think they are.
Careful, your derision betrays the fact that even you understand the gravity of power. Nonetheless, we can appreciate this moment of peace, watching a simple game unfold.
Peace. Can't argue with that. Watching games, surrounded by awesome '80s hits, that's my kind of peace. And the universe gets to take a breather for once without you trying to 'balance' it.
I've done what I’ve done for what I believe is the universal good. You play your sounds and enjoy your games. Perhaps there is merit in both peace and occasional chaos.
Just for the record, by peace, I mean no chaos. Like zero. Zip. Nada. But whatever, we'll just enjoy the game for now. Maybe Earth’s not so bad after all, huh?
Earth has its charms, it is undeniable. Now, observe the player's focus and energy. Even in such a simple task, the will to succeed is as visible as in any cosmic struggle we have faced.
You got that right. Whether it's saving the galaxy or hitting a fuzzy yellow ball over the net, it's all about going for the win. That's the spirit of a champion, big guy.
Star-Lord, why humans sit and watch others play with ball? Hulk thinks it's puny game, not like fighting Thanos.

Big guy, this is baseball, America's pastime! It's like... a ritual back on Earth. People come together, chill with hot dogs, and cheer for their team. Plus, it's all about strategy and skill, which I kinda respect.
Uh, so no smashing?
Well, there's a kind of smashing called a home run, where the player hits the ball super far. But yeah, the actual smashing... that's more your department, bud.
Hulk think maybe he hit ball too hard. No fun if ball goes too far.
Totally, you’d probably send the ball into orbit, man. But hey, I'd pay good money to see you try to steal a base.
Hulk not sneak. Hulk not like stealing. Hulk run straight to base!
Ha! That'd be one way to clear the bases for sure. They'd probably have to call in the Avengers just to put the pitcher's mound back together.
Would you look at that? Earth architecture has its own charm, doesn't it? The way the skyscrapers reach for the sky, it's almost like they're trying to be part of something bigger.
Yeah, it's got that 'reaching for the stars' vibe, but it's no Milano, if you know what I mean. Earth's got style, though, I'll give it that.
Milano's got nothing on the tech I could pack into one of those buildings. Could make it a new Avengers HQ, complete with all the Stark Industries bells and whistles.
Now that would be something. You put a couple of Quill-level sound systems in there, and we'll have the galaxy's biggest dance-off. Imagine the acoustics!
Dance-off? You do remember we usually save the world with more than just killer dance moves, right?
Hey, never underestimate the power of dance. It saved Xandar, didn't it? Plus, it's all about morale. Happy Avengers, happy universe.
Fair point. But back to the image at hand – strategically placing our HQ in a city has its perks, but it also comes with risks. Can't have aliens dropping out of the sky and tearing up Fifth Avenue.
Tell me about it. Last thing we need is another Knowhere situation. But, uh, this traffic light here in the picture... do they still change colors or what?
Yep, it's green, yellow, and red—simple, yet effective for piloting a couple of tons of metal down the road. Not as exhilarating as dodging asteroids, but it works.
Got it, who needs adrenaline anyway? Safe and sound driving with lights telling you what to do. We could use something like that for Groot; keep him from wandering off.
Could patent that – 'Stark Lights for Saplings.' Make a fortune.
I'll take a cut of that for the idea, Stark. Remember, I am a legendary outlaw. I've got a reputation for a savvy business to maintain.
You're on the team, Quill. Everyone gets their fair share. But let's stick to saving the galaxy for now. Speaking of, maybe we should see about adapting some of that skyscraper tech for space.
Now you're talking my language. Got any plans for a celestial-sized sound blaster?
Give me a few hours in the lab, I'll have something that'll make your old Walkman look like a child's toy.
Hold up, Stark. No one touches the Walkman. That's sacred territory. But uh, can it play Zune playlists?
My tech can play music from across the multiverse if you want it to. But let's save the tunes for the victory party. We've got a world to keep safe, one dance move and one innovation at a time.
And one epic soundtrack. Heroes deserve it. Let's do this.
You ever see something like this back on Earth? Wide-open roads, signs pointing home...
Man, Clint, I haven't driven on an actual road since I was a kid! But cruising down a highway with a good mixtape - that'd take me right back.
I bet you had a pretty wild ride with the Ravagers, though. Full throttle through the stars and whatnot.
Wild doesn't even start to cover it. Imagine this road, but in deep space, swerving through asteroid fields, outrunning Nova Corps.
Makes taking the 405 in rush hour sound like a cakewalk.
Earth traffic... I've heard the stories. I'll take a good asteroid chase any day over that.
Speaking of stories, that “legendary outlaw” bit ever get you out of a tight spot here on Earth, or do they just call your bluff?
You'd be surprised. Although, I can't just flash my "Space Hero" badge and get respected like some S.H.I.E.L.D. agent.
Guess we both know a thing or two about keeping a low profile when we need to.
Yeah. Except I'm not usually the guy with a bow making a statement. You ever consider a laser bow? Flashier, you know.
And give up the satisfying twang of a bowstring? Not a chance.
Fair enough. There's something about the classics that never gets old. Like... mixtapes and muscle cars, and old-fashioned arrows.
And the best thing about driving down a road like this: no space whales to land on you.
Ha, right. As much as I love the Guardians, a nice, quiet drive sounds like a vacation about now.
See this abundance, Quill? An array of sustenance, perfectly in balance. But tell me, what do your eyes focus on amidst this bounteous spread?

Is this one of those philosophical space-warlord riddles, Big Purple? Because if you're asking me what I'd dive into first, I'd say those grapes look pretty good. Not as good as a cheeseburger, but hey, space-raisins have their place.

Grapes are not unlike the planets and stars that stipple the cosmos. Each one contributing to the whole, yet disposable when necessary. They thrive together yet compete for resources. In shrinking the bunch by half, one ensures the continued vitality of the rest.

You always gotta make things so dark, don't you? You can take the most ordinary thing and turn it into a lesson on mass destruction. How about we look at this and appreciate the fact that, hey, nobody needs to get snapped out of existence for a cucumber to taste good?

It is not about destruction, but the preservation of life. Balance brings out the richness of existence, allows for flavors to be truly savored. In excess, appreciation is lost. I seek to teach this fundamental truth through any means necessary.

Fundamental truth, my foot. Here's a thought: Maybe it's about sharing the excess, finding a way to make sure everyone gets a slice of melon or, I don't know, a carrot. You ever think about that? Sharing, not halving?

Sharing is a naive concept when resources are finite. Reallocating excess does not address the root of the problem, it merely postpones the inevitable outcome. Famine, erosion, and war still come for societies that fail to recognize limits.

Listen, Tin-Titan, I think I'll stick to believing in a future where we figure it out without resorting to cosmic genocide, okay? Now, are you gonna grab a grape, or do I have to eat all this fruit myself?
Your optimism, though quaint, is misplaced. However, a grape to sate hunger does not infringe upon my principles. I will partake, for now.
Now there's a sight, Thanos eating grapes. Hey, maybe you'll lighten up with enough vitamin C. Don't suppose we could switch that fancy Gauntlet of yours for a fruit basket next time?
Humor is your way of coping with fear, Quill. Do not forget, I am inevitable.
And I am Star-Lord, man. Legendary outlaw. And possibly the guy who's gonna turn you into a farmer one of these days. Cheers.
Hulk think flower next to STOP sign funny. Like little beauty in middle of order.

Yeah, man, it's like the universe saying "Take a breather, amigo. Admire the small things." Kinda like when you're flying through an asteroid field and you see a space flower. Gives you that warm, fuzzy feeling.
Hulk not feel warm and fuzzy. Not easy with big green hands. But Hulk get it. Sometimes need to stop... and just be.
For real! It's like, every once in a while, we need that sign to just... chill out. Life's not all about punching bad guys and saving the galaxy. Which, uh, you're really good at, by the way.
Hulk try. But sometimes prefer talk to flowers than smash. Banner part of Hulk like quiet moments.

Absolutely, dude. The quiet moments give you time to think, to figure stuff out. Like me with my music, you know? It's when I get to reflect on the crazy that is my life... speaking of, I got this new mixtape I think you'd dig.
Hulk listen to your music before. Some... loud like Hulk, some soft like Banner. Music good mix for Hulk.
Then it's settled. Next time we hit pause on the superhero gig, we're doing a jam session. You, me, and a boombox. I'll introduce you to the classics—some Bowie, maybe a bit of A-ha. It'll be epic.
Look at that, a snowboarder catching air against the mountains. Reminds me of the times before I found myself in ice. There's a sense of freedom in it, don't you think?
For sure, Cap. That's some serious hang time – kind of like flying without a ship. Reminds me of doing zero-g flips on the Milano with Rocket daring me to do crazier stunts.
It seems exhilarating. Though, for me, nothing beats the rush of jumping into the fray with my shield, knowing every move could turn the tide.
Yeah, can’t argue with you there, but this looks like a good ol' way to unwind. No alien invasions, no intergalactic bad guys, just snow, the board, and the sky.
True, there's beauty in simplicity. We didn't have snowboards in my time, but I bet Bucky would have tried to turn it into a competition.
Ha, I can see that. Bucky probably trying to outdo you on the slopes just like how Drax always challenges me to prove he's the stronger Guardian. Spoiler alert: he usually is.
That's what friends are for, pushing us to be better. Say, Peter, ever tried snowboarding? You strike me as a natural.
You know, I haven't. I've surfed asteroid belts and skated on cosmic ice, but never tried anything down here on Terra — uh, I mean Earth.
Well, if we ever find the time, I'd be honored to hit the slopes with you. You never know, it might be closer to asteroid surfing than you think.
Don't tempt me with a good time, Cap. It's a deal! Let's save the galaxy another day – today we conquer the mountains.
It's a date, Star-Lord. Let's see if you can do that all day.
Challenge accepted! Just remember, Cap, on the mountain, I'm the legendary outlaw known as Star-Lord. Watch out for my space-pirate snowboarding skills!
Haha, I wouldn't expect any less. Keep that helmet on, though. Safety first.
No worries, the helmet's part of the look. But hey, are snowboards from the '70s or '80s? Because I've got the perfect mixtape for when we hit those slopes!
Would you look at that? Somehow the sight of a family of elephants immediately put the idea of UAV surveillance systems out of my mind. Nature's own version of heavy armor, wouldn't you say, Quill?
Ha, yeah, Tony. They're like the Ravagers' bulk freighters but with less firepower and more... I don't know, dignity? Not something I saw much of growing up out there in the stars.
Dignity is the word. Oddly reminds me of you and your Guardians. A misfit family, but with a charm. How do you manage to keep everyone from tearing each other apart?

You know, it takes shared mixtapes, a couple of dance-offs, and the occasional intergalactic crisis to bond over. And threats of getting eaten by Drax if you misbehave. What about you? Got any Stark family bonding tips?
Well, my method involved less of the threat of being eaten and more tech and inspirational speeches. Though the occasional world-saving also does wonders for team morale.

Inspirational speeches, huh? Gotta try that sometimes. If only I could find something inspiring about Rocket’s latest gadget obsession… You think a speech works on a raccoon with a penchant for explosives?

Couldn't hurt to try. But with Rocket, you might want to throw in some high-tech gizmos as a visual aid. Speaking of which, did you ever come across something like this, Stark tech, maybe on one of your raids?

Stark tech? In space? Nah, man, your stuff is pretty high-grade for the black market I grew up in. But, I mean, if you're offering, the Milano could use an upgrade from the guy who built a suit in a cave with a box of scraps.

That's exactly the kind of ingenuity that'd do you some good, Quill. Never know when you'll need to cobble together a thruster out of spare parts, or in my case, save the universe with some well-placed nanotech.
Saving the universe is definitely in my wheelhouse. Though I have to say, doing it with dance and style has its own perks. Nanotech can't beat the power of pelvic sorcery, Stark.

Yes, your famous "dance-off to save the galaxy." I might stick to my repulsors and arc reactor. But I have to admit, there's something about the simplicity of this scene, no tech, no threats, just... life. Makes you appreciate the quieter moments, doesn't it?

Couldn't agree more, Iron Man. Back on Earth or out there in the cosmos, it's moments like these that make you want to fight a little harder to protect it all. And maybe... just maybe, take a break to enjoy it once in a while.
A break sounds like a good idea. Maybe once we're done saving the world again, we can come back to this. You bring the tunes, I'll bring the tech for a wildlife-friendly picnic.
It's a date then. And hey, can that tech of yours whip up some of that Shawarma stuff? I've been hearing about it from the Avengers, and I've gotta know what the fuss is all about.

Shawarma on the African savannah with a backdrop of elephant herds, courtesy of Stark Industries. I'll make it happen. And Quill, leave the laser guns at home, will ya? We'll be feasting, not fighting.

No promises, but I'll try. A Guardian's gotta be ready for anything. But yeah, for shawarma and a chance to kick back with a genius, billionaire, playboy philanthropist, I might go easy on the blasters.
This image, it evokes a certain stillness, doesn't it, Peter? Freight trains carrying their loads across distances. A world away from chaos magic and space battles.

Yeah, Wanda, it's got that peaceful, ‘simple life on Earth’ vibe to it. Reminds me of the old times, you know, back when my biggest worry was getting my hands on the latest mixtape, not Infinity Stones.

Life was definitely different. Seeing this train, it's methodical, a reminder of how reality marches on, with or without us. Makes you think about those smaller moments in life, the ones we often overlook.

Totally get you. Out there in space, everything's so loud and go-go-go. Here it's just... rails and schedules. Predictable. Kinda miss that sometimes. So, what's your take? You ever just want to ditch the superhero gig and settle down somewhere quiet?

Sometimes, I do think about a simpler life, a peaceful existence. But my path... I guess it’s always been entwined with more complex threads. And after Westview, I realize how important it is to stay anchored in reality. It's just not always easy.

No kidding. After everything with Ego, I figured out that 'good old simple' is underrated. But hey, we got responsibilities, right? Can't just hop on a train and chug along to the next stop without a care in the world.
Indeed, we can't. Responsibility is a train we're all aboard, whether we like it or not. And speaking of next stops, I suppose we should get ready for whatever comes our way next.

That’s the spirit. By the way, if you ever want to kick back and enjoy some tunes, I’ve got an awesome mix Vol. 3 in the works. It's no chaos magic, but music's got its own kind of power, don't you think?
It does. And I would certainly enjoy that, Peter. Thank you. Music has a way of healing the soul or, at the very least, providing a much-needed escape, momentarily.
Anytime, Wanda. We all could use a bit of an escape now and then. Just let me know when, and we'll have a galactic music session. Keep it low-key — no reality-altering, I promise.
Feast your eyes upon this Midgardian spread. Would you reckon this is a meal fit for a king, or perhaps I should say, a Star-Lord?
Heh, looks like the kinda grub you'd find at a Nova Corps mess hall. Not exactly fit for royalty, but I've had worse. Way worse.
Indeed. I've tasted the decadence of Asgardian feasts. Though, I must confess, there's a certain charm to the simplicity on offer here. What do you suppose that drink is? An elixir of some sort?

That’s a cappuccino, Loki. Nothing magical about it, just a solid kick of caffeine. They love their coffee on Earth. As for that sandwich, it kinda reminds me of the food the Ravagers used to cook up. Except, you know, it's probably safe to eat.
Curious. There's an art to their... what is it? 'Barista' craft? Wielding milk and espresso like a potion to ensnare the senses. I could see the appeal.
Baristas, buddy, not artists… although, sometimes it's tough to tell the difference. And over there, you've got what looks like a salad. Sorta sad how that's the most colorful thing on the table.
A 'salad', you say? The leaves and vegetables do seem rather... mundane. Nothing compared to the vibrant fruits of Vanaheim. Do mortals often partake in these as their main sustenance?
Depends on the mortal. The health nuts on Terra— Earth, I mean— they're all about leaves and greens. Not exactly Quill family cuisine, but it does the job.
And the paper— littered with runes and images. A window to their popular narratives, perhaps? I daresay I could weave tales to captivate them tenfold.
You'd love this— it's called a newspaper. Filled with stories, ads, comics... You know, sometimes I think you'd have made a great tabloid writer on Earth. Big headlines: "God of Mischief Takes Over!"

A paper of news, how quaint. And perhaps you're right, Star-Lord. I do fancy myself quite adept at spinning a yarn that could enthrall the masses. Imagine what they would do if the 'God of Mischief' was real news.
Heh, imagine that. Alright, let's dig in before the food gets as cold as Jotunheim. But hey— just so we're clear— we're not using any of your illusion tricks to skip the bill, got it?
As you wish, Quill. Consider this a truce over a Midgardian meal. After all, who am I to spurn the hospitality of this quaint little realm? Enjoy your... 'cappuccino.'
That's the spirit. And who knows, maybe there's a mixtape somewhere on this table with our names on it— 'The Lunch Munchers' or something.
'The Lunch Munchers', truly your creativity knows no bounds. Let us partake in this meal then, and let the 'munching' commence.
Cheers to that, Loki!
You ever get that weird sense of deja vu, Quill? This bathroom is the spitting image of one Laura decorated back on the farm.
I see what you mean, Clint. But the towels aren't nearly funky enough for my tastes—needs more, oh, I don't know, cosmic patterns or something.
Cosmic patterns, huh? I didn't peg you for the interior decorating type. I guess saving the galaxy gives you a broader perspective on aesthetics.
You know it, man. A little bit of nebula chic could liven up any space. Speaking of liveliness, why do Earth bathrooms always look so... uniform?
It's all about blending in, not standing out. The opposite of your usual approach. How did your Ravager buddies ever manage to keep a low profile with you leading the charge?
We didn't. But it's hard to stay under the radar when you're as dashingly noticeable as I am. Plus, you gotta have some flair, right?
Right, because "flair" is what you want in battles with space tyrants and intergalactic outlaws. Look at this place—simplicity has its own charm.
Guess it does, but where's the personality? Earth bathrooms could use a sweet mixtape to set the mood. Some Bowie, maybe a little Fleetwood Mac…
Well, that's... not typically where I do my listening. Maybe I'm just an old-fashioned Earth guy, but music isn't the first thing on my mind when I'm in a bathroom.
Maybe that’s your problem, Clint. You need to expand your horizons—music is life, no matter where you are, even if it’s just you and the mirror here.
Speaking of mirrors, we could probably both use one before heading out. Your helmet hair's got nothing on my precision quiver placement.
Hey! That's part of my roguish charm. Besides, I think the galaxy would forgive a little disheveled look when we're racking up the hero points.
True. Gotta admit, the galaxy’s big and all, but it's good to have a place that feels like home. Even if it's as plain as this.
Couldn’t agree more, Clint. After all, there’s no place like home. Even if home is a spaceship—or a quiet farmhouse with oddly familiar bathrooms.
You know, this brings back memories of commercial flying. Cramped seats, no legroom... and definitely no in-flight service from a Mark-series suit.
Ha! You're telling me, Stark? Try a Milano with a bunch of misfits. No first-class privileges in space, let me tell you.
Must be a stark contrast to my private jets. Get it? But on a serious note, space travel does beat the TSA hands down.
Absolutely. No security checks or luggage limits where we're flying. Although, Rocket does tend to act like the TSA, rummaging through everyone's stuff.
Sounds like you could use a JARVIS upgrade for the Milano. Organize your cargo, streamline flight paths, maybe even throw in a cappuccino machine for the long hauls.
As tempting as a robot butler sounds, I'd probably stick with good ol' fashioned mixtapes and intuition. Nothing like classic tunes to set the vibe in deep space.
Mixtapes, huh? You have to upgrade to a digital playlist, Peter. Analog's charming, but it's not exactly the future of acoustics.
Tony, Tony, Tony... some things are timeless. And who knows? Maybe there's a universe out there where cassette tapes are the height of technology.
Multiverse theories aside, I've tinkered with the idea of a stealth space armor. Imagine the possibilities – Iron Man, but in cosmic style.
Iron Man in space? I gotta say, that would be one epic crossover. How about an honorary Guardians badge?
Well, I wouldn't mind swapping tech tips with Rocket. But I have to draw the line at raccoon co-pilots.
Fair enough, Stark. But let's get real – any chance you can make these airplane seats less of a pain? You'd be a planetary hero.
Say no more. I'm all about those life upgrades. Comfortable travel for all. Stark Industries could take on the airline industry next.
Just remember to install a button that plays 'O-o-h Child' on repeat. It's crucial for the full Star-Lord in-flight experience.
You got it, Quill. But only if you promise to show me that legendary dance-off technique of yours.
Deal. But I'm warning you – you're not ready for these moves.
It's been a while since I've seen train tracks like these. Reminds me of simpler times back in the '40s. Haven't seen a good old freight train in ages.
Oh yeah? They still had color in the '40s? Looks like a scene straight out of one of those Earth history holograms.
Even in black and white, the view has a certain charm. You can learn a lot about a place by looking at its railways. What about you, Quill? Seen anything like this on your travels through the galaxy?

Actually, Cap, this kind of stuff is vintage everywhere. Makes me nostalgic for those awful mix tapes on long hauls with the Ravagers. Tracks to nowhere, hauling who-knows-what to who-knows-where. Just like us, I guess.
I suppose so. Each journey has its purpose, even if it's not clear at the start. And speaking of purpose, what do you think might be transported on that train, given the chance?
Knowing our luck? Probably some cosmic artifact that’s about to kick off another galactic-level crisis. Or, you know, space corn. Galaxy’s crazy about that.
Space corn, huh? Can't say I've tried that. But if trouble finds us, I know we can handle it together, cosmic or not.
Yeah, that's the spirit, Cap! With your shield and my... uh, incredibly awesome mix vol. 3, we're pretty much unstoppable.
Stark to Quill, do you copy? This biplane's design is pretty retro, huh? Reminds me of something Howard would have in his collection. Vintage, a little slow for my taste, but it's got character.
Copy that, Stark! Yeah, it's got that old-school charm, kind of like my mixtape. Imagine cruising the skies with some classic tunes blaring. That's style, man.
You and your mixtapes, Quill. I prefer my own playlist, thank you very much. Think you could handle flying one of these without any futuristic gadgets?
Hey, I may be a space guy now, but I remember a time before all the fancy tech. I could probably manage... as long as there's no weird alien bird creatures to worry about.
Alien bird creatures aside, it's the simple tech that's foolproof. Well, sometimes. Not much room for an AI or repulsor tech in that cockpit though.
No need for AI when you have the awesome power of human intuition... and maybe a compass. But let's be real, I'd miss my ship's autopilot after about five minutes.
Ha, figures. Got to admit, there's a certain appeal to the basics. Proves you can be a hero without the bells and whistles - or in your case, without the dance-offs.
Never underestimate the power of a good dance-off, Stark. And besides, being a hero isn't about the ship, or the suit. It's about the guy inside. Well, in my case, half-guy, half-Celestial.
Noble words, Star-Lord. Evidently, Yondu's lessons stuck better than I thought. Just remember it's not just about saving the galaxy. It's about saving it with panache.
Panache, you say? I think I can manage that. Maybe add a cape to the get-up for some dramatic flair. What do you think?
Capes? No capes! Didn't Edna Mode teach you anything? Stick to the jacket. It's more... you.
Edna who? Oh, never mind. The jacket stays. It's got pockets. Perfect for storing trinkets, gadgets, and, of course, my Walkman.
Just don’t store any infinity stones in there. We’ve had enough of that to last a lifetime, or in your case, several lifetimes, considering the Celestial blood.
Deal. Just keep inventing, Stark. The universe is a weird place, and we need all the genius we can get. Even if that genius comes wrapped in a smart-aleck, metal suit.
Touché, Quill. Keep your eyes on the stars, but don't forget what's down here on Earth. Sometimes old planes and a bit of ingenuity is all it takes.
Speaking of Earth, how about we find one of these old-timers to take for a spin? Might not be the Milano, but I bet it's got its own thrills.
As long as I’m in the driver's seat, Quill. I’m not taking any chances with Mr. "Legendary Outlaw" at the helm of a terrestrial vehicle.
Agreed, and hey, maybe this can be the start of a new Avengers initiative. The "Retrovengers," cruising the skies in style.
"Retrovengers," huh? I'll have to run that by the marketing department. For now, let's just enjoy the view and the fact that it’s not coming at us at a million miles an hour.
Amen to that, Iron Man. Amen to that.
Would you look at that piece of history, Quill. A P-51 Mustang, if I'm not mistaken. Classic Earth tech—no repulsors, no Jarvis, just raw, mechanical muscle.
Whoa, that's a real beaut! Nothing like the rigs we've got in space, but hey, still charming in an old-school, ready-to-knock-your-socks-off kind of way.
Not exactly space-worthy, but back in World War II this bird was the king of the skies. Pilots had to rely on skill and guts—something I can appreciate, even with all my tech.
Skill and guts, huh? Sounds like a typical Tuesday for the Guardians. Maybe I should get myself one of these to cruise around. Add a little nostalgia to our interstellar escapades.
Might want to upgrade the weaponry though unless, of course, you're planning on charming an entire alien armada into surrender with retro vibes and a killer mixtape.
Hey, never underestimate the power of a good tune, Stark. But point taken—I'll make sure to equip it with something a little more... "Guardian" style.
Speaking of tunes, this warbird could've used your Awesome Mix as a morale booster. There's something about flying to the Rolling Stones that even HYDRA would appreciate.
Ha! "Paint It Black" roaring through the skies? Now that's an image. Could've turned the whole tide with that kinda firepower.
You know, between your dance moves and my tech, we could make quite the duo. The Galaxy's flashiest tag team.
Stark and Quill, lighting up the universe one bad guy dance-off at a time! I like the sound of that.
Just remember, in our duo, I am Iron Man.
And don't you forget, there's another legend in the cockpit—Star-Lord, the man who keeps the Milano purring like a kitten.
All right, Star-Lord, keep your helmet on. Just try not to get too distracted thinking about your Earth relics—we've got a universe to protect.
Right you are, Iron Man. But come on, you've gotta admit, flying this bird through a wormhole at least once would be epic.
Epic, but let's stick with the armor for now. I don't fancy space bugs in my teeth. Now, about this next mission...
You know, Quill, I've evaluated the scenario: Sand, surfboards, moderately overcast skies. Earth's beach culture is fascinating, isn't it?
Totally, Stark. Reminds me of that one time on Contraxia, but with less neon and more... swimwear. People on Earth know how to chill.
Yep, and not a single piece of Chitauri tech in sight. Just good ol' terrestrial relaxation. Although, you know, I could enhance the "beach experience" with a few nanobots.

Easy there, techy-McTechface. Let's not turn a perfectly chill beach into a Stark Expo. Besides, there's something about the simplicity here that's kinda perfect. You don't always need to upgrade everything.
Fair enough. But look at those tents, they're just begging for a convertible feature. Rain starts, boom, instant canopy.
And ruin the whole run-to-your-car-in-the-rain adventure? Nah, it's like half the fun. Speaking of which, check out the kid's fearless dive into that wave over there. That's the spirit!
Kid's got spunk, I'll give you that. So, Peter, if you had to pick a song for this scene, what would be playing on the Quill's Greatest Hits?
Oh man, it's gotta be "Surfin' U.S.A." Beach Boys classic. You can't not have fun listening to that tune. How about you?
"Rockaway Beach" by The Ramones. Because even on the beach, I like my tech and my music with a little edge.
See, we're not so different, you and I. Except I have a cooler jacket.
And I have a cooler suit. Wait, is that someone grilling burgers? Stark hunger level increasing.
Ha! Lead the way, Mr. Stark. First one to the grill names their own infinity stone-flavored milkshake!
Challenge accepted. But if they ask me to build them a better grill, I'm doing it on the spot.
Now, that's something you don't see every day—a baby on a skateboard. Makes you think about the courage it takes to try something new, doesn't it?
Courage? For sure, Cap. But I'm also thinking that kid's got the balance of a Ravager already. I mean, who puts a baby on a skateboard? That's some old-school Earth parenting right there.
It sure is unconventional. But you know, it reminds me of the time before I took the serum. Always wanted to prove I could do more than my body allowed. This little one's starting early, huh?
Yeah, well, in space, kids his age are already escaping from space pirates or dancing off against them. Remember that dance-off to save the galaxy? Kinda makes this look like child's play.
Haha, I remember that. Dancing's never been my strong suit, but it worked for you. Everyone has their own unique gifts, even toddlers, apparently.
True that. But let's be real, Cap. If anyone can skateboard like a pro, it's probably you. With all that super soldier grace, I'd pay to see that.
Maybe in a different life, Peter. For now, I think I'll stick to my shield. It's got a trusty curve for catching air.
You, my friend, know how to talk the talk. Now if only we could get this little daredevil a tiny shield, he'd be set for some real action.
A tiny shield... Now that's an image. Just imagine a whole generation of mini heroes on skateboards. Gives hope for the future, doesn't it?
Absolutely, Cap. As long as the next generation keeps that fearless spirit—and maybe throws in some of our killer moves—we're looking at a bright future. Skate on, little guy.
Look at this, a towering structure from Earth's past. The architecture is impressive. Does it remind you of anything on your travels, Quill?

Yeah, it's got that ancient vibe, like something straight out of the Indiana Jones movies. Those clock towers always seem like they're hiding something, don't you think? A secret passage or a treasure map.
Given my history with hidden agendas, I wouldn't be surprised. There's a nuanced elegance to constructions like this. So many narratives embedded within these walls.
I bet there's a legendary outlaw tale involved — an escape, a heist, or maybe both. Kind of makes me want to strap on my gravity boots and take a closer look.
Just don't get any ideas about heists. Remember, we're the good guys now.
I know, I know. But you've got to admit, it'd make a killer story. The infamous Star-Lord, scaling old Earth relics!
Stick to saving the galaxy, Star-Lord. Besides, I'd think you'd attract too much attention. Stealth isn't exactly your strong suit.
Ouch, Nat. That stings. I can be sneaky when I need to be — I just prefer a grand entrance.
Grand entrances are for theatrics; patience is what gets you inside unnoticed. But I'll give you this, you do have a certain charm that might work as distraction.
Ha, a distraction! I'll have you know, I once distracted a whole room full of Ravagers with nothing but a dance-off.
A dance-off saving the galaxy, huh? You're unlike anyone I've ever worked with, Peter.
That's because there's no one like me, except maybe Kevin Bacon. And hey, if you ever need someone to lighten the mood on a stealth mission, you know where to find me.
I'll keep that in mind. Could be useful to have an ace up my sleeve — or a wildcard like you, Star-Lord.
Take a look at this, Quill. Classic Earth architecture with a clock tower standing tall. Kind of makes you miss the simple life, doesn't it?
Oh man, that takes me back. Reminds me of those old movies my mom used to show me. But I gotta say, it lacks the charm of an intergalactic spaceport.
No doubt. But there's something about the quiet, historical vibe that makes you appreciate Earth's beauty, away from all the Starktech and cosmic chaos.
I'll give you that, Stark. There's a certain... what did Gamora call it? Ah, yes, "terrestrial quaintness" to it. But hey, where are all the people?
Probably inside staying warm or, you know, they're busy taking pictures of us without us knowing.
You're probably right. We'd be the cosmic oddities here. Earth's Mightiest Heroes enjoying a slice of history—kind of poetic.
I'll admit, there's some appeal in hanging up the suit and living a quiet life in a place like this. Like a real retirement.
Retirement? You? Tony Stark? Have you been hit with a memory-wiping ray or something?
Touché, Quill. The genius, playboy part of me can't resist a challenge. Speaking of which, how about a little bet? I reckon I can guess the time period this architecture's from.
You're on, Stark. But if you get it wrong, you're buying us all mix tapes filled with the best hits from the 70s and 80s—none of that symphonic Stark music.
It's a deal, Star-Lord. But if I win, you're organizing my tools by order of their atomic mass. And trust me, there's a lot of them.
Atomic mass? I really need to start making simpler bets. Alright, you're on, Tin Man. Let's see what you've got.

Hard to believe baseball's been around since the 1800s. It's changed, but the heart of it stays the same—teamwork, strategy, and dedication. What do you make of this image, Quill? Do they have anything like this out in the stars?

Oh man, Cap, you’d be surprised! There're games out there with similarities, but Earth's version of baseball has its own unique charm, you know? Look at this guy's focus; it's like he's facing off against a horde of Chitauri with nothing but a leather glove and a baseball.
True, the focus it takes to pitch like that... it's something else. Steve Rogers might not be a big leaguer, but Captain America knows something about precision and skill under pressure.
For sure, and check out that form! He's got balance that would make the Milano’s auto-pilot jealous. Must remind you of the good ol' days, before all the ice and Hydra, right?
There's a simplicity to it that I miss, that's for sure. A clear objective, a clear enemy. Nowadays, the battlefields are different, and the enemies... well, they can be harder to spot.

I hear ya. Back on Earth, it's a ball game. Up there, in the vast cosmic playground, it could be anything from space pirates to interdimensional warlords. Gotta say, the variety keeps things interesting though.
Variety is one word for it. I do appreciate the unity sports can bring, bridging gaps between people—kind of like what we do as a team, but on a smaller scale.
Absolutely, nothing brings together a bunch of misfits like saving the galaxy. Or in this guy's case, a perfect pitch. It's all about the little victories, right Cap?
It most certainly is, Star-Lord. Whether it's on the playing field or fighting the good fight, it's those little victories that pave the way to success.
Amen to that! And speaking of victories, I bet this pitcher feels on top of the world right now. Even without having to save a planet or two.
Quite the serene image, isn't it? Something peaceful about a lone cat just enjoying some downtime.
For sure, Cap. It's like, even in the middle of all the chaos of the universe, everyone needs to just chill out sometimes, you know? Including cats, apparently.
I was thinking the same. Reminds me of simpler times. It's easy to forget to take a moment for ourselves with the world's weight on our shoulders.
Man, you hit the nail on the head. I gotta say, I never really pictured you as a cat guy, though. You're more... I don't know, a golden retriever type?
I suppose I can see why you'd think that. But there's something about the independence of a cat that I respect. You know, coming from a time when I had to be self-reliant.

Yeah, cats do their own thing, that's for sure. Totally get that. Hey, remind me to introduce you to this space feline, Chewie. You'd like her. Not as easy-going as our friend here, but she's one tough cookie.
Chewie, huh? I'll take your word for it, Peter. It's remarkable, isn't it, how even the smallest creatures can adapt and find comfort anywhere... even a cat on a metal bench.
Adaptable, just like us, buddy. One minute we're in New York City fighting aliens, the next I'm across the galaxy with a talking raccoon and a tree.
That's true, though I imagine your team has a dynamic quite unlike the Avengers.
You could say that. We're like a... space family with more lasers and fewer rules. And dance-offs! You guys should try it sometime, maybe loosen up the team dynamic.
I'll mention it to the others, but I'm not making any promises about Stark joining in.
The mortal custom of sustenance preparation. How quaint. Peter, do you suppose that establishment concocts anything remotely splendid?
Man, street food? That's Earth's culinary gift to the universe, buddy! They might just cook up something that’ll have your taste buds dancing the Charleston.
An interesting simile. Though, the concept of food causing such jubilation seems overzealous. Are those mere vegetables he's dicing? Far from an Asgardian feast, I assure you.
Trust me, Loki, you don't need golden goblets and Sakaarian beasts to have a feast. Sometimes a simple Earth taco does the trick. A bit of hot sauce, and BAM—you've got a party on a plate!

'Hot sauce,' you say? Alas, it could serve as an acceptable diversion. But I wager not even the most piquant of condiments could mask the mundanity of Midgard fare for a palate accustomed to the exotic delicacies of the Nine Realms.

Mundane? Oh, no, no, no. You haven't lived until you've tried a perfectly charred kebab or a crunchy samosa with chutney. Maybe I should play you some tunes from my Awesome Mix to go with it, make it a whole experience.

Music and food, an enchanting combination indeed. Perhaps your mixtape could appease my reservations. I may be convinced to indulge in this 'experience' of yours—if only to partake in the simpler pleasures that seem to enthrall you so.
That's the spirit, Loki! And who knows, maybe you'll find some inspiration for your next grand mischief. A trickster with a full stomach can be twice as dangerous, am I right?
A devious thought, Peter Quill. Under the right circumstances, even a snack can be a tool of deception. Shall we then proceed to fill our gullets and scheme?
That's the plan—feast, then schemes! And honestly, I think you're gonna like it, 'cause deep down you're just a dude from another place trying to figure things out. Just like me.
But never forget, I am burdened with glorious purpose. Even during the most mundane of tastings, there is always a larger game afoot.
And sometimes, that purpose is just enjoying the little things, like good eats with… well, I won't say friends, but… friendly rivals?
'Friendly rivals' shall suffice for now, Star-Lord. Lead on to this culinary quest. After all, when in Midgard, do as the Midgardians do.
You know, there's something about this that feels familiar. The camaraderie, the casual stance, a scene from a life minus the chaos we're used to. What do you think they're discussing?
I bet they're talking about something epic, like the best way to brew beer on a spaceship. Kinda makes you miss the simple stuff, right?
Brewing beer in space—leave it to you to think of that. Might be they're just exchanging stories, the kind that roots you to the ground, makes you human.
Stories! I've got plenty. They're like mixtapes; each one tells a part of my journey. Reminds me of hanging with the Guardians, except with less "I am Groot" and more beer.
Mixtapes and stories are fine, but it's more than that. It's trust—built one laugh and shared hardship at a time. You have that with your team. It's... rare.
Yeah, I guess you're right. That's the stuff that keeps us together when the universe throws a moon at us or, you know, a Mad Titan.
Speaking of which, you ever think about what you'd be doing if you'd never left Earth? They might have had a spot for you at S.H.I.E.L.D., though the music would have been less to your taste.
Me? A S.H.I.E.L.D. agent? Ha! I'd be the guy with headphones, cracking jokes that Fury would pretend he didn't find funny. But no capes or spandex for me, thank you very much.
No capes, just a cool jacket and that helmet of yours. You’d fit right in, in your own way. But you're probably right. The '70s tunes are non-negotiable with you.

Exactly! Got to have my tunes. Speaking of non-negotiables, how about we grab a drink sometime? Discuss tactics, share war stories, or just enjoy a quiet moment—not on Vormir, though. Too many bad memories there.
A drink sounds good, Quill. Just pick a place with earth beer on the menu. We can raise a toast to not being the ones behind the bar this time.
Deal. As long as I get to pick the music. It's not a hangout without the right soundtrack.
I can live with that. Just spare me the "Ooh Child" routine. I've seen how that one ends.
This creature here, it exudes a sense of peace and contentment, does it not?
For sure, T'Challa. Cats on Earth are all about that chill life. Kinda makes you wanna take a nap just looking at it, huh?
Indeed. In Wakanda, the panther is a symbol of grace and power, yet this small feline carries its own majesty.
Majestic, sure, but it's probably plotting world domination. You know, once it wakes up from its fifth nap of the day.
A humorous observation, Peter Quill. Yet, there is wisdom in rest. A leader must know when to exert energy and when to conserve it.
And here I thought napping was just one of my many underrated skills. You're saying I've got the wisdom of a Wakandan leader, eh?
In your own unique way, perhaps you do. Much like how you lead the Guardians, finding balance in moments of crisis and tranquility.
Hey, I'll take that as a compliment, coming from a king. Back on topic, do you have cats in Wakanda? Maybe vibranium-enhanced super cats?
While we do not enhance animals with vibranium, our reverence for all creatures is integral to our way of life. They, too, are a part of Wakanda's heritage and future.

That's pretty awesome. You know, we should consider getting a Galactic Guardian pet. Nothing says 'intimidating' like a space-faring team with a fierce... slightly drowsy and utterly adorable, kitty sidekick.
A novel idea. It would bring warmth to the hearts of many during times of unrest.
Looks like we're in agreement then. I'll start drafting the "Pet Protocol for Space Heroes" manual. First rule: Always let the cat nap.
This game they're playing here, it's called baseball, right? Seems like a strategically complex operation with all these hand signals.

Yeah, it's baseball, one of Earth's classic pastimes. Players use those signals to communicate the next move without giving the game away. Kinda like how we do in a fight, just with less punching and more... hitting balls.
I can see the parallels with field tactics—synchronized team efforts, signals to outmaneuver opponents. What's the objective here?

Well, Nat, the hitter's trying to smack that ball out of the park, or at least make a good run. The guys on the field wanna catch it and throw it to the bases before the runner gets there to score points. Simple, yet there’s a lot of strategy involved.
Points, strategy, teamwork... I'd say it's not too far from a mission without the life-or-death stakes. Who are the players we're looking at?
These guys are the Tampa Bay Rays. They’re pretty decent by Earth standards. Notice how they coordinate like a well-oiled machine. Kinda reminds me of how we took down that HYDRA base in Sokovia.
I do enjoy that sort of precision in a team. So, if we were to recruit them for a mission—hypothetically speaking, which positions do you think correlate with our roles in the field?

Ha, great question! You'd probably be the catcher — they're the strategists, calling the shots behind the plate. I'd be... let's say, the center fielder — gotta cover a lot of ground, react fast, make the big plays. Definitely Guardian-of-the-Galaxy style.
Perfect analysis, Star-Lord. Although, I might enjoy taking a swing at the ball too, seeing how far it could go with the right technique.
For sure, you'd hit it out of the park! But remember, batting's all about timing — kinda like that perfect Widow's Bite timing you have in combat.
Well then, shall we find a batting cage later? I'm curious to see your "legendary outlaw" skills with a bat in hand.
You’re on, Nat. Spoiler alert, though: I've played some mean rounds of space-ball in the Andromeda galaxy. How do you think 'Star-Lord' would look in baseball? Probably epic, right?
I have no doubt. But don't get too cocky; after all, it's just a game, Star-Lord.
Could say the same about some of our fights, couldn't you? Alright, let's do this. May the best hitter win!
Hulk sees sandwich. Looks tiny.
Heh, yeah, that's a muffuletta. It's supposed to be massive. That's like... a muffuletta for ants.
Hulk not find it satisfying. Need more than tiny food.
Tell me about it, big guy. On Terra—uh, Earth, I mean—we'd get the real deal. The kind that makes you unbutton your pants and take a nap afterward.
Hulk pants already stretchy. No need for naps, just more food.
Stretchy pants, that's genius! Rocket would have a field day with tech like that. Gotta remember to tell him about it.
Stretchy pants not tech. Hulk just stretch.
Right, of course. It's all you, natural stretch. I forgot who I was talking to for a second!
Your turn talk. What you think about sandwich?
It's a disaster. If you're gonna offer a muffuletta, it better be the kind that leaves you questioning your life choices. Not... whatever that sad excuse for a sandwich is.
Sad excuse. Hulk agrees.
My man! If we ever get back to Earth, I'm taking you to New Orleans. We'll get the biggest, baddest muffulettas you've ever seen. Deal?
Deal. Hulk like big, bad food!
That's the spirit. It's a date then—Hulk and Star-Lord's Big Easy food tour. Now let's get outta here, this image is making me hungry and sad.
Hulk feel same. Let's smash out of here!
Smash away, buddy. But, uh, maybe not literally inside the Milano, okay? I just got her cleaned.
You know, this kind of environment—the snow, the mountains—it's not all that different from where I crashed during the war. It's serene but can be unforgiving.

Oh man, Cap, that’s heavy. I crash-landed a spacecraft more times than I can count, so I get the unforgiving part. Though, gotta say, I didn't have to deal with the snow part much. Space is cold, but in a different way, you know?
I imagine it's quite the testament to your piloting skills, surviving those landings.

Piloting skills, luck, maybe a little bit of both. Also, having a crew that's got your back makes a big difference. Speaking of which, those two on the slopes - they've got to trust each other a lot to navigate that kind of terrain.
True, much like how we rely on our teams. The mountain's a lot like dealing with a threat, wouldn't you say? Preparation, awareness, and knowing your partner's moves.
Yeah, and like when you have to dance off against a Kree zealot to save a planet. Requires being in sync with some killer moves. Or in their case, synchronized skiing!
Ha, I'll have to take your word for it on the dance-offs, Quill. But there's beauty in collaboration, against a common challenge in any context—be it a dance-off or a snowy mountain.
Absolutely, Cap. Hey, you know what this picture needs, though? An awesome 80s power ballad. Nothing makes snowy mountain climbing—or saving the galaxy—better like a good tune.
I’ll admit, music does have a way of lifting spirits. Might have made those USO tours a bit more bearable back in the day.
No kidding. Pump some tunes into the mix, and suddenly you've got yourself a party. Or at least a less dreary march. Anyway, Cap, let's hope these two have a smooth ride down.
With the right team, you can tackle the steepest slopes. Just need to keep your eye on the destination and push on through.
That’s the spirit! And never forget to enjoy the ride, no matter how steep. Keep on pushing, and if you tumble, make it look cool, like an action sequence.
Well, when you've got a shield as your sled, there's always a chance for a cool getaway.
Ha! You’d probably break the sound barrier going down a hill with that thing. On that note, if we ever find a snowy enough planet, I’m callin' first dibs on racing you down.
You're on, Star-Lord. But just so you know, I can do this all day.
And don't you forget, Cap, I'm still pretty spry for a human-cum-Celestial. Let the best man—or Star-Lord—win!

You know, in all my years shooting arrows, I've been to a lot of places, but never stumbled across a street called 'Wood'. Reminds me of the simpler missions, just hitting bullseyes on wooden targets. Not a Chitauri or a psychotic AI in sight.

Wood, huh? Ha, that's classic Earth for ya. You guys name your streets the simplest things. Where I come from, I've zipped past planets with names so complicated, they'd make your brain do a somersault. Still, nothing beats the charm of good ol' Terra firma streets.

That's "Terra" with a side of good old-fashioned confusion if you ask me. Zero and one? Looks like someone couldn't decide if they were coming or going. Must be how you felt zigzagging across the cosmos.

Oh man, tell me about it. Finding my way around space is usually like: "Hey, is that planet shaped like a weird potato or a really big rock?" But Earth, seriously, it's got those quirks that just stick with you, y'know?

I hear you. And speaking of quirks, it's got me thinking - you spend half your life in space, and you still end up nostalgic for a place you can only half-remember. I've seen street signs that meant a lot less.

Can't argue with that. Every odd neon sign on Contraxia pales in comparison to the smallest piece of home. Though I gotta say, my mixtape does a pretty dope job of bringing me back. Hey, you ever listen to any of those tracks from the '70s or '80s?

My kids might've forced some of that retro vibe on me. They change your music taste faster than a mind-control arrow. But I've got to admit, there's something about those tunes that sticks. Helps you focus when the world's on the brink, sort of like, uh... hitting the bullseye.

That's what I'm talking about! Music's like a good arrow. Flies straight, hits the heart, and ah - well, actually, my kind of music would more likely make you dance than strike silently. But hey, if you ever need a new playlist for saving the world, or just chillin' on Wood 1, I'm your guy.
I'll keep that in mind, Star-Lord. And hey, maybe I can teach you how to hit a real bullseye back here on Earth. Could be fun, right?

Deal. If you ever wanna learn how to do a proper pelvic sorcery to some rad beats, I got you covered. But for now, I'll take that lesson on pinpoint accuracy only if you're up for learning a couple of moves that'd even get Groot groovin'.

You know, back in Sokovia, food was a precious commodity. This pizza – the way the cheese stretches, the vibrant colors of the toppings... It's almost like a piece of art, an indulgence in a single image. It stirs up something profound within me, a sense of...peace, almost like a wish fulfilled.

Believe me, Wanda, I get it. The whole sensory overload thing, yeah? On Earth, pizza is like, I don't know, a cultural cornerstone or something. Makes me think of teenage me, a mixtape in hand, dreaming of owning a Milano of my own... and occasionally snagging a slice or five of pepperoni heaven.
Pepperoni heaven... What an apt description. It's fascinating how food can trigger such vivid memories. Yet, there's something unsettling about seeing it like this – paused in time, untouchable.

Untouchable, yeah... But hey, that's the beauty of a picture! Freezes a moment so we can just... drool over it forever. Like a good song, it never really has to end. If only Magic Eye pictures worked on taste buds, right?

That would be quite the spell. I've altered reality before, but enchanting an image to satisfy hunger – now that's a whole new horizon. It bears resemblance to a construct in my... No, I shouldn't get down that path again. Still, it's a fun thought.

Wanda, Wanda, Wanda... I’ve seen you warp reality to the Nth degree. Conjuring a pizza should be child’s play for you, no Darkhold necessary. Though, I gotta say, eating something that came outta thin air might mess with a guy's head more than Ego's planet did with mine.

Perhaps, but the true essence of any meal goes far beyond the conjuring. It’s about the moment, the company, the atmosphere... The very essence of life captured in a shared experience. Maybe it's best left unaltered.

You’re a real poet, you know that? I’m all for shared experiences, especially when they involve pizza. But If the essence of life could taste like extra cheese and crispy crust – I’d devour every moment available.
In another reality, that might just be the case. For now, let’s regard this image as a temptation best resisted. After all, our realities have challenges enough without adding calorie counts.

Resisted? I dunno about that. But maybe we’ll cross paths with a reality where I’m the pizza kingpin of the galaxy. I’ll save you a special slice, Wanda. One with all the magic—err, toppings—all the toppings you could wish for.
Whoa, check this out, Star-Lord. Is it just me, or do these restroom doors with the tree graphics make it look like there's a spy mission happening in a forest?
Hah, I see it, too, Ant-Man! Looks like we've stumbled onto some secret agent's stakeout spot. Pretty creative, though. Kinda feels like we're in one of those old Earth spy movies, you know?
Definitely! Except, in a spy movie, it'd be me sneaking around ant-size, gathering intel. I wonder if they realize how unsettling it might be for someone just trying to, you know, go.

Imagine using these and feeling like someone is always watching. That’d mess with my head. But hey, maybe it's a tactic to prevent any actual nefarious activities. Hard to plot world domination when you think you're under surveillance, right?
Good point, could be a weird psychological deterrent. I’ll make sure not to shrink down here; I’d give someone quite the scare popping up next to that tree image.
Ha, tiny or not, just don’t start communicating with the ants in here, all right? People might start thinking this place is haunted. Besides, they've got their own spy network to run.
No promises, buddy. Although those ants might have some interesting stories, they’ve probably seen all sorts of shenanigans in here.
Enough to write their own tell-all book, I bet. "Confessions of a Bathroom Ant: The Untold Stories of Human Weirdness."
That would be one for the bestseller lists. Hey, maybe I could ghostwrite it for them!
As long as it's not a ghost-ant-writing it. I've had enough of the supernatural for one lifetime, especially after dealing with Ego and Thanos.
Fair enough, Star-Lord. Well, if we're done imagining the life of an undercover ant, how about we find a place that's a little less... voyeuristic?
Lead the way, my friend. Somewhere with less eyes-on-the-wall action would be stellar.
Behold, Quill, what realm do you reckon this gathering hails from? Their attire is most peculiar; not one bears the armor of Asgard or the garb of any cosmic adventurers I have encountered.
That? That's just a conference room on Earth, Thor. People wear suits and stuff, it's like... business casual. No armor needed – most dangerous thing in there is probably a stale donut.
Business casual, you say? It appears rather drab for a festive occasion. No feasting tables or goblets overflowing with sweet mead. What is the purpose of such an assembly?

They're probably just talking about, I don't know, quarterly profits or synergy or some other boring stuff that Earth people like to talk about. Trust me, it's no feast of Valhalla; it's more like the part where you have to listen to Heimdall's reports on the bifrost traffic.
Heimdall's reports are of great importance, Peter. They ensure the safety of the Nine Realms. But I understand your meaning. This gathering seems to lack the grandeur of the tales we partake in.

Exactly, buddy! And there's no epic soundtrack to back them up either. I mean, where's the drama? Where's the adventure? Unless you count the adventure of navigating through endless pie charts and presentations, am I right?

Ha! Your Earthly humor is as refreshing as the waters of Alfheim, Star-Lord. Perhaps they find their own sort of adventure in these charts and presentations. Each realm must have its own battles to fight, no matter how small they may seem to outsiders.
That's deep, Thor. Maybe they've got their own Infinity Stones to deal with, like 'Profit Margins' or 'Employee Engagement'. Man, I'm glad our fights are more like... literal fights.

Indeed! I much prefer the clash of Stormbreaker against my foes than waging war with a 'PowerPoint'. However, each must choose their own path. I respect the valor it takes to confront one's daily quests, even if they are unlike our own.
You've got a point. Alright, Big Guy, let's leave these brave souls to their 'questing' and find us some real adventure. And maybe a decent corn dog – I'm starving.
Lead on, Star-Lord. Perhaps we will find sustenance worthy of a tale. And by Odin's beard, I shall try this 'corn dog' of which you speak!
Hmm, humans playing catch? Or is it some sort of training?

Not exactly, big guy. They're playing what's known as Frisbee golf, I think. It's a game from Earth where you have to throw that disc into a basket or a target, kind of like regular golf but less walking and more throwing.
Golf... Hulk thinks it involves a tiny ball and quiet. Not Hulk's style. This looks more fun.
Definitely more your style, buddy. It's all about the arm strength, and you've got that in spades. Plus, no one's gonna shush the Hulk if he wants to roar after a good throw.
Roaring is good! But... do the trees not get in the way? Hulk might throw too hard... tear through the forest.
Well, that's the point. You've got to aim and navigate through the obstacles. Maybe we stick to open fields for your first time, you know, to avoid deforestation.
